members.name: Arbor Low Ley - Derbyshire/Staffordshire
members.description: This ley, which is particularly suitable for ramblers, starts at a tumulus near Foolow in Derbyshire's High Peak, with its stone walls and rolling, spectacular scenery, and travels SSW for 16 1/4 miles over Arbor Low stone circle and across the N end of Dovedale to a beautiful sacred well near Ilam, just within Staffordshire.

members.name: Avebury Ley - Wiltshire
members.description: This alignment runs SE-NW for 71/4 miles, crossing the NE section of Avebury.

members.name: Bradgate Ley - Leicestershire
members.description: A ley of contrasts. It runs N.W. for 9 & ½ miles from the SE of Leicester, across the city's most ancient quarter, then over one of its industrial areas, finally reaching picturesque Bradgate Park on Charnwood Forrest. The development of an alignment discovered in the field by David Potts.

members.name: Cambridge Ley - Cambridgeshire
members.description: This ley runs for 13 1/2 miles NW from Wandlebury, across Cambridge and terminates in Swavesy. Its first marker is the great round barrow (49715290) on Wormwood Hill just SW of Wandlebury Fort.

members.name: Canterbury Ley - Kent
members.description: Canterbury Ley

members.name: Cerne Abbas Ley - Dorset
members.description: 7 miles long, this ley runs SSW from Holwell to Cerne Abbas, situated a few miles N of Dorchester.

members.name: Devil's Arrows Ley - North Yorkshire
members.description: The Devil's Arrows (39126650) are three Bronze Age standing stones, giant monoliths ranging in height from 18 feet to 221/2 feet, the tallest stones in Britain apart from the Rudston monolith. There used to be at lest one other stone near the middle one, but that was used to make a nearby bridge a great many years ago. The stones are of millstone grit and were brought nearly 7 miles from Knaresborough. The legend associated with the megaliths states they are arrows fired by the Devil to destroy the nearby town of Aldborough, but have fallen short of their target.

members.name: Glastonbury Ley - Avon/Somerset
members.description: The name of Glastonbury immediately conjures up images of King Arthur and mystic Avalon: a sacred centre shrouded in delicate mists. As it happens, Glastonbury provides exactly this appearance in real life, with the whole area dominated by the extraordinary Glastonbury Tor - a sacred hill if ever there was one. This ley passes through Glastonbury and the Tor, commencing in the N of what used to be Somerset (now Avon) through to Butleigh near the heart of the Glastonbury zodiac. It is a development of research by Janet Roberts and John Mitchell, who has shown it to be part of a system of leys around Glastonbury defining the cryptic geometry of the 'New Jerusalem'.

members.name: Long Man of Wilmington Ley - Sussex
members.description: This ley runs SSW-NNE for just over two miles from Friston Forest, over Windover Hill and the Long Man, to the village of Wilmington. It seems as if other leys may pass through and near the Long Man, and we in no way claim this to be the best.

members.name: Maiden Castle Ley - Dorset
members.description: Stretching for just over 8 miles SE-NW across the countryside immediately S of Dorchester, this ley runs from Warmwell Church to tumuli at Winterborne Steepleton.

members.name: Mayburgh Ley - Cumbria
members.description: This alignment is on the East fringe of the Lake District. Starting in the ancient town of Penrith by the M6, the ley goes almost due S to the church at Askham, 31/2 miles away.

members.name: Men-an-tol Ley - Cornwall
members.description: This is just one of the number of alignments noted by John Michell in The Old Stones of Land's End. We have already mentioned Michell's Boscawen-un ley (p.46) as an alignment of such precision that it takes the question of the existence of leys clear outside the realm of statistical probability. This one, from Men-an-tol, runs fractionally N of E for 3 3/4 miles.

members.name: Montgomery Ley - Powys/Shropshire
members.description: This ley runs for 53/4 miles SE-NW through unspoilt countryside in and out of the border between Shropshire and Powys (Wales).

members.name: Old Sarum Ley - Wiltshire/Hampshire
members.description: This is another classic alignment originating with Sir Norman Lockyer, though in this case we have modified the line by extending it to the S and marginally changing its angle.

members.name: Rollright Ley - Northamptonshire/Oxfordshire
members.description: From an earthwork by Chipping Warden in Northamptonshire, the ley runs from 16 3/4 miles SW to the Rollright stone circle in Oxfordshire. A difficulty to watch for when attempting to plot leys through the Rollright Stones is that their relative positions on the 1:50,000 and 1:25,000 scales do not quite tally. A small difference, but enough to seriously affect ley hunting.

members.name: Rudston Ley - North Yorkshire/Humberside
members.description: The ley runs NW-SE for just over 10 miles across the undulating wolds of what used to be called the East Riding of Yorkshire.

members.name: Silbury Hill Ley - Wiltshire
members.description: This ley runs for 13 miles NNE-SSW through Avebury and Silbury Hill.

members.name: St. Paul's Cathedral Ley - London
members.description: This church alignment stretches for just under 3 1/4 miles WSW-ENE across the heart of Old London. It is a slightly modified Alfred Watkins ley, being extended to St. Clement Danes in the W, with the bearing altered a little. The orientations of all the churches approximate - sometimes very closely to the bearing of the ley, but do not coincide exactly.

members.name: Stonehenge Ley - Wiltshire
members.description: This is the classic line discovered by Sir Norman Lockyear and extended by K.H. Koop. A modified version of it was used as a ley by Watkins before he read Lockyear. It is 22 miles in length, crossing over Stonehenge in a generally SW-NE direction.

members.name: Strand Ley - London
members.description: An unmodified Alfred Watkins alignment, running for a little over 2 1/2 miles SW-NE linking the line of parts of Pall Mall and the Strand. Because the ley falls 'approximately on part' of these famous roads, Watkins felt the alignment was verified as a track.

members.name: Uffington Ley - Wiltshire/Oxfordshire
members.description: Running a little E of N, this ley covers 9 3/4 miles from a tumulus some distance S of the M4 motorway to the village of Uffington in Oxfordshire, crossing the White Horse and Dragon hills on the way. The whole alignment takes the ley hunter through quiet rural scenery and the swell of the Downs.

members.name: Walterstone Ley - Hereford and Worcester/Gwent
members.description: An unmodified Alfred Watkins ley stretching for 4 miles across the lush countryside of SW Herefordshire and the convoluted Welsh border.

members.name: Weston Beacon Ley - Devon
members.description: Weston Beacon Ley

members.name: Winchester Ley - Hampshire
members.description: The course of the ley runs from the N of Winchester SSE through the ancient city itself, over St.Catherine's Hill to its S, and terminates in a tumulus beyond that. It is just under 11 3/4 miles long.

members.name: Moeller
members.description: A geographical analysis of the lines by Jens M. Möller

members.name: St. Michael Line
members.description: St. Michael Line

members.name: Apollo-St.Michael Axis
members.description:
The Apollo-St.Michael Axis in 3 different versions:
  • A direct line (Straight) from Skellig Michael (Co. Kerry, Ireland) to Stella Maris Monastery (Mount Carmel, Israel).
  • A line (Follow) along the places Skellig Michael (Co. Kerry, Ireland), Saint Michael's Mount (Cornwall, UK), Mont Saint Michel (Normandy, France), Sacra Di San Michele (near Turin), Monte Sant' Angelo on the Gargano peninsula (Italy), Stella Maris Monastery (Mount Carmel, Israel).
  • An approximate circle

members.name: Syria Pentagram
members.description: Syria Pentagram

members.name: Ancient Sites and Alignments of West Penwith
members.description: This is a map of the ancient sites and alignments in West Penwith and in neighbouring areas. The Lizard, Isles of Scilly, Kerrier and East Penwith: these areas form a backdrop to the visual and geomantic landscape of ancient West Penwith. Penwith is a distinctive, mostly cliff-bound, island-like area, with a magical atmosphere and a ruggedness to the land and its residents. Trencrom Hill and St Michael's Mount act as geomantic gateposts to the peninsula. Nowadays, Penwith is at the end of the road, far from metropolitan England, but in ancient times it was a marine node in the Atlantic megalithic world.
